Reviews.Content: Fast, easy to use and great resolution.Only hitch, battery must be removed to be recharged but it is easy to do.

Reviews.Title: Pleased with this camera
Reviews.Author: B. Gries
Reviews.Content: Purchased this about 3 months ago to replace my old Casio Exilim point and shoot. I have been very pleased so far. We shoot mainly in intelligent Auto mode which does a good job of face recognition and is very fast adjusting to the proper mode. Low light photos are fine. Not miraculous by any means but it definitely gets the job done. I also like the 8x optical zoom and the ability to zoom during video is a great feature. The power-on-to-first-shot time is very good. A plus for parents with young kids.The HD video is a nice option at this price point. We mainly use the AVCHD lite mode. Although this is somewhat of a drawback as it's not a standard format, you can still download them directly to YouTube. There is also motion JPEG mode, but it takes up more memory. So there are options there. The menus are pretty intuitive so this camera has a pretty quick learning curve.All in all I was amazed at how much better technology was in this camera compared to my ~5 year old Casio ultraslim. Definitely worth the money.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use
Reviews.Author: Cowlady
Reviews.Content: Very easy to use.  Didn't need to read all instructions to use in automatic mode.  Good quality pictures.  Have used video function once ... also very easy and good results with great sound from quite a distance.  Very small and compact.

Reviews.Title: Easy to use, great pictures.
Reviews.Author: kleiowa
Reviews.Content: This camera takes crisp, clear images and is easy to take out of the box and begin using. A perfect mid-range point and click digital camera. I rated the video low to medium, because I haven't used this functionality on it yet. Very happy with this camera!

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money.
Reviews.Author: gbest777
Reviews.Content: I've only had the camera for a short time but in my first week of ownership I find myself very happy with the camera. The included software could be much better especially for the video. The video this camera takes is pretty good but I wish that the software could be configured to export video files into a separate folder than the picture files. I would have liked to see a better video editing solution. The fact that the owners manual is only on the CD is rather disappointing. The naming convention is also more confusing than my previous cameras. That said I am very happy with the quality and build of this camera. I'm happy with the pictures it takes and I am much more likely to get those precious video memories recorded now that I can easily switch to video and don't have to switch to my video camera. I might add that I am very impressed with the quality of sound capture in the video.

Reviews.Title: intuitive
Reviews.Author: bigguy
Reviews.Content: I had less than a week to familiarize myself with this camera before a trip to the Galapagos.  I had no trouble using the IA setting and just shooting.  Great photos from a trip of a lifetime.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Taw
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my 13 year old daughter for Christmas and she absolutely loves it.  It is small and easy to use and takes better pictures than her old Kodak.  She has been running around trying all of the various features and has been ecstatic about the results.  Very happy with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera with good dim light photos
Reviews.Author: K. Schwartz "thirty-something"
Reviews.Content: I did a great deal of research before choosing a camera.  I settled on this one because of my desire to have decent photos in low light conditions and this camera was supposed to provide that -- AND BOY DOES IT!  I am very pleased with the quality of photos, especially ones I never could have taken on my old camera.  Pretty easy to use, about the size of a deck of cards.  I love that the shutter is built in so I won't lose the cap of have my children taking it off.  I wouldn't have spent $279 retail, that just isn't in my budget for a camera.  But I got it for $169 through Amazon.  Amazing deal!  Thanks Amazon!

Reviews.Title: A Step Above Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: TheoDoor
Reviews.Content: We were in the market for a new camera but didn't think we were quite ready for an SLR.  This seemed to be somewhere in between an SLR and point and shoot and the price was right, so we got it.  We decided on this one because of the 720 video and haven't been disappointed.  The only thing a little weird about the video is the default format which didn't play well with the computer.  However, you can change it to a PC friendly format and now life is good.The actual pictures are great as well and the 14mp leaves a lot of definition in case you want to do some cropping.

Reviews.Title: camera review
Reviews.Author: Clare in Milford
Reviews.Content: I'm a new-comer to the digital world, so can't compare to others.  My kids tell me it's a great buy.  (I'm a "senior.") I'm still learning how to use the various options; but so far I like it very much.  The zoom is great for my wild-life and other long distance photos.  It's so small I can carry it everywhere - tuck it in a pocket or in my purse.  I'd recommend it to other new-comers.

Reviews.Title: Love it, Good camera for great price
Reviews.Author: Two Cool
Reviews.Content: Been playing with it for a couple of hours today.  I must say it takes wonderful pictures and captures lots of details in a shot.  Lots of things to play with in the settings and must say the 8x optical zoom is pretty nice.  If you're looking to capture shots at the full 14.1 mp quality, I would recommend at the minimum a 4g SDHC Memory card.  But if you can afford it go ahead and get the 8 gb SDHC memory card because 14.1 megapixel shots are going to take up lots of space.

Reviews.Title: Great Purchase!
Reviews.Author: Doozi
Reviews.Content: Very satisfied with this purchase!  I did my research & found a camera that had everything I wanted (and then some).  Got a great price through Amazon!  Great little camera; has all the features a novice could possibly need and plenty of options for seasoned photogs as well.  In fact, this camera does SO much, I haven't even had a chance to really study all that it can do to take advantage of all the features!  Love the MP's, optical zoom, large LCD screen, easy navigation and size.  Also like having the ability to zoom while taking a video.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3
Reviews.Author: R. H.
Reviews.Content: For a point and shoot camera, it is excellent. The price was fair for what I would have paid for it.This camera is an update of our previous camera. Which we love. That camera is an 8mp camera, but the little door that keeps the batteries in place broke on the end. The camera still works, but I really don;t want to have to put a piece of tape on it to keep the little door shut (it still works, but the door is slightly open - which bugs me)On this camera, the battery locks into place - I LOVE THAT!, if the door breaks, it won't matter, because the battery and the memory card each lock into position without the need for the door to even be there at all. That one feature is worth the camera.It comes with a battery charger and it appears (so far) that the battery it comes with lasts a very long time. If I was to use it on vacation, I'd think that I could take pictures all day long and recharge the camera at night, so you probably do not need an extra battery. If you foresee taking a LOT of pictures, often, and not being around power to recharge the battery, you might want a spare battery.The pictures and ease of use are amazing.I am a full time professional videographer. Often, stories can be told very well, artistically with still images for the video. I have done this several times with excellent results professionally... for family or creative fun projects, I can see a lot of people making use of this type of camera, small, easy to use and fun to play with... and it won't (or shouldn't) break your budget! It does shoot video too, and that could be incorporated into your projects for even more creativity.

Reviews.Title: small and easy to use
Reviews.Author: L. Mantzaris
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  I haven 't used it that much, but what I have done has beenterrific.  It takes great pictures and is easy to use. Just what I wanted.

Reviews.Title: Best ever!!!
Reviews.Author: J. Buffolino
Reviews.Content: The video quality is that of an expensive, professional video camera. I have 2 other digital cameras, one a Sony and one a Cannon. None of them have the quality of my Panasonic. Can't wait to take it on vacation with us, I can imagine all the pictures and videos I'll take. I LOVE IT!!!

Reviews.Title: Put this in the camera bag with your DSLR
Reviews.Author: SpeedoNJ "Len"
Reviews.Content: I've been looking through the ZR and ZS camera selection for a while now. You know you're always looking for a little camera to carry around when you don't feel like dragging out the DSLR?  This might be it!I bought this through the amazon outlet, where I've never been disappointed.  It was "Used-very good" If you haven't used the outlet, don't be afraid.  Well, don't pay 95% of new price either, but when it's 20%+ off, what you'll get is as nearly new as you can get.  My guess is, shown by camera reviews here, is that there are a lot of finicky people who return cameras after using or not using them for a couple of days. So there's that, plus I wanted to try something like this on the cheap.Well, it works. Buying at agreat price and the results being so good make me very happy.I'm comparing this against:Sony W370Nikon S80Lumix FP8All are similar size, zoom, megapixels, price etc.The Sony has an expanding lens, the other two are internal optical zoom. Of these, the Nikon is probably the best, and it does very good video.So the ZR3 is better than these three and will be my pocket camera.  The pictures are as good as the much bigger Nikon Coolpix P series, which are much bigger cameras with much higher zoom.  It's just about as good, maybe the same, as my three year old P80, but of course not as good as a new P500. But I wouldn't pay $400 for a ZS7 (that's the current amazon price, it's usually less expensive) just to have things like GPS and otherwise wouldn't do much more. Put another way, if you want to spend the $400, buy the new Nikon P500.Keeping on topic, Lumix are great cameras all around, vibrant colors, excellent contrast, many user options.This is a fine companion camera, it is small enough to fit in you pocket easily even in the smallest case and will yield impressive shots because you'll be able to have it on hand when an occasion happens when you otherwise wouldn't be lugging around your bigger stuff.And if this is the only camera you'll have, that's cool too.

Reviews.Title: A camera worth buying
Reviews.Author: Taonian Chen
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera based on the following reasons:1. The lowest price compared with other name brand cameras of the similar features;2. Full use of optical zoom while capturing movies;3. Intelligent use of the camera;4. Excellent picture and movie quality.The only con of the camera is the compatibility of movie file format with the computer and HDTV. You have to install QuickTime to play movie on the Window XP or Vista computers, or convert the video file using third parties' video converter software, as the media player can't play the HD movie captured by the camera.The camera's HDMI port is not compatible with my Sony Bravia HDTV. The TV doesn't recognize the camera's signal from HDMI input.After a few months of use I found that the pictures taken in low light (even with built in flash) are grainy. However, I still recommend this point-shot camera at an affordable price.

Reviews.Title: Weak flash
Reviews.Author: Monette U Gousset
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera with much excitement. I had a older version of the panasonic lumix, that I just absolutely loved. I very seldom had a bad picture, and if I did, it was my fault. With this camera, the flash is too weak. Subjects just 2 feet away in medium light with the flash will come out dark. So, so disappointed. I just got this camera in December, and I am now looking for a new camera.

Reviews.Title: good pocket camera!
Reviews.Author: wonka
Reviews.Content: it's a good pocket camera, has a good zoom, and the battery lasts for a long time without using the flash!good pictures, not too soft and an ok low light quality photo!recomended

Reviews.Title: Anazing little camera!
Reviews.Author: Joeywankanobe
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a pocket camera. I'm a professional Photographer and hate lugging around my SLR's all the time. This camera performs great in daylight! As good as my SLR's! Low light?...come on...there are very few cameras that do well in low light...kinda like your own eyes! No light...no see!But for general snapshots of friends and scenics...its absolutely amazing! Very pleased...and it fits in my pocket so nicely.

Reviews.Title: Best digital camera I have ever owned.
Reviews.Author: HuskerShane
Reviews.Content: There are 2 features that I love the most about this camera that I haven't seen matched in this price range.  The wide angle is fantastic.  I am in the custom cabinetry business and can get great pictures that were impossible with other cameras.  It is able to capture the entire wall of the room without me having to back clear out of the door.  I also love the zoom.  I can really reach out and get great close-ups at a distance.  This camera has so many features that I am still learning how to use them all.  The only somewhat negative comment that I have at this point is that I wish the battery life was a little longer.  Maybe I will just have to invest in a back-up battery.  However, I am very satisfied with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Good point and shoot
Reviews.Author: AHUPFELD
Reviews.Content: I bought the ZR3 for my wife, who works as phisioterapist at a major children clinic in Sao Paulo. Main purpose was to register her patients' evolution in small videos and pics, on the go. The camera had to be small (to fit in her shirtpocket) and fast (the patients usually don't pose). What she found really nice was the separate "video" button, allowing her to rapidly toggle between video and photo modes.

Reviews.Title: Need  a little patients
Reviews.Author: Ron
Reviews.Content: To begin with the low light photos are in fact horrible but you can reduce the exposureand have  a great shot. I shot a few pics in bright sun light but colours were washed out so I increased exposure again great shots so I strongly suggest adjusting  exposure  even though (point & shoot) auto should be worry free as every thing in life needs a little adjusting.The feel of the ZR3 is compact switches and togglessecure I would have liked the to exchange the selection wheel with the shutter but I've already gotten used to it .The video @avchd is crisp looks great on  the PC I do recommend the zr3

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Dennis D. Watters
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera with one exception.  If the sun is behind you, you can not see the view finder.  Other than that this camera is fantastic.  Even with the shortcoming I would not trade it for another.

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: Dr.Girlfreind
Reviews.Content: This by far is the best camera that I have ever owned, and to make it even better, it is a very pretty shade of blue.It's easy to use and takes great pictures.There is an option on it to taker video, it's not the greatest quality video, but it will get the job done.I love the fact that it has a rechargeable battery, so I'm not adding to battery waste.I would definitely  suggest this camera to anyone I know looking for a a new camera.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC ZR3
Reviews.Author: frenchie9700
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for our trip to Hawaii that we took last week.  When I got the camera I put it together, and snapped a few pictures to make sure it worked alright then put it away until our trip.  It worked fine the first day.  On the second day a black spot appeared in the upper center of my LCD screen.  I tried to clean the lens with lens cleaner, but the spot remained.  Since I had no other camera to use I took my vacation pictures hoping it was the LCD screen and not the lens.  When I got home I downloaded pictures to my computer, and to my dismay spot was on most of my vacation pictures.  I called Panasonic and got nowhere.  They wanted me to send camera to McAllen, Texas for someone to look at it to determine if it was a defect.  If it was, which it obviously was to any idiot, they would send me a refurbished camera.  This did not sit well with me as the camera was brand new, and they wanted to replace it with what would be basically a used camera.  I then called Amazon, and told the man my story.  He said since I could not get satisfaction with Panasonic and I had a case number with Panasonic they would issue me a full refund for price of camera but it would have to go through their Large item department.  He told me he would personally handle it to make sure I got that refund.  Panasonic would not give me the option of taking my camera to a local repair shop and have them pay for it or reimburse me.  Also, Amazon considers cameras hazardous materials and would not accept it as a return for an exchange.  I got an e-mail next day saying that they cannot take it as a return and to call them to determine how best to proceed.  Got e-mail after department closed so I did not know if I would get that refund.  My husband called next day, and they said they would issue full refund and apologized for the camera ruining our vacation pictures.  I never did hear back from the man who said he would personally make sure I got that refund though.  I think Panasonic has very poor customer service.  Thank you Amazon for standing behind Panasonic's faulty camera.

Reviews.Title: Reliable and Good Quality Point & Click
Reviews.Author: ignorant_intellectual
Reviews.Content: Pros: Lightweight, easy to use, good quality pictures, high zoom, long battery life, - everything you need from a simple point & clickCons: Minimal features(I have owned the camera for 2 years and it has worked great)

Reviews.Title: zr3 review by RF4CPLT
Reviews.Author: Robert L. Neese "af plt"
Reviews.Content: good buy for the money at 150ish.  Seems durable, takes decent pics (for great pics I have a Nikon SLR) and it is the right size to fit in your pocket.  8x zoom provides good zoom capability with camera in your hand (good stabilization).  More than 8x zoom would require a tripod for virtually any camera.  Color is decent too.  I recommend this camera based on my limited use so far.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera with awesome HD video quality
Reviews.Author: Maheswar Vayugandla
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera almost 6 months back and pretty happy with the purchase. Small in size, fits in pocket but does not compromise on quality. The iAuto (intelligent Auto) mode works great for still pictures. I did not experiment with other modes as iAuto worked for me in all situations so far. I was looking for a camera with good HD video quality and found this one. I don't have to maintain a camera and camcorder as this has both the features. I bought a 16gb card and that is enough for hours of video.

Reviews.Title: Horrible.  Don't buy it.
Reviews.Author: SCM
Reviews.Content: I regret to say that this might be one of the worst camera's I've ever had the misfortune of owning.  After months of research, I landed on this model because of the Leica optics and the effusive reviews of the Panasonic line.  It was, to say the least, a disaster and though I don't usually do such things, I returned it and am still using my 3 year old Casio EXS600 which despite a relatively low megapixel rating, blows this camera out of the water in terms of sharpness, clarity and color balance.  I'm a former pro photographer who has owned a lot of equipment over the years and I cannot believe how bad this camera performed.I tested it outdoors on a sunny day and on both ends of the lens - wide angle and max zoom (with the digital zoom disabled because), the noise was hideous - as it was for all focal lengths in between.  The term sharp seems foreign to this camera.  Auto-focus is nothing more than murky concept to this unit.  I tested it on various shooting modes for close ups and other scene modes and maybe 1 out of 15 turned out sharp and clear. But that's not the worst of it.The flash, was particularly weak as well but even that isn't the worst part.  The color in shots indoors were horrendous.  No matter what I did to adjust any of the settings, shooting under indoor lights using a flash turned out hideously mis-colored shots that would require copious amounts of Photoshop to fix.  I shot pictures side by side with my trusty old Casio and was horrified to see the yellow, and green hues (from tungsten and fluorescent lights) coloring the parts of the photo that the flash was too weak to illuminate.  Several co-workers took one look at the photos and said - "take it (the Panasonic) back - it's a joke."  I honestly wanted it to work, read the manual from cover to cover and tried to excuse it and figure out if the settings were somehow at fault.  But my trusty old Casio and everyone else's cameras (I work in Marketing and graphics are a part of what we all do), some newer, some older,  compensated just fine for the indoor shots, while this one failed miserably.  I called Panasonic, and asked what I might be doing wrong and their only answer, from a person who clearly knew nothing about photography and was obviously reading from some online user's guide said to "reset" the camera.  I'd already tried that - so I was done.  Vanns to their credit, shipped quickly, and did a quick and efficient return and refund for the camera.  I applaud their service and would not hesitate to purchase from them again.  However, this camera is a bad joke.  Avoid it like the plague.

Reviews.Title: Poor indoor shots
Reviews.Author: Quilt Girl
Reviews.Content: I picked up this camera as a temporary replacement to our Canon G10 that died after 18 months. When I found out it would cost at least $200 to fix, the hope was that this could fill in the time until I could afford a canon DSLR. I was sorely disappointed. Indoor shots with ample light always required the flash, and came out horrifically orange to the point that the picture was worthless. I worked with customer service with Panasonic to no avail, so this is being returned and exchanged for the high-end Lumix that I borrowed from a friend.  Also, for some reason my computer won't recognize any of the video files, so I was never able to get them off the camera. Yes, this is probably my fault, but I'm not tech illiterate in any sense.

Reviews.Title: Blurry outdoor photos, red-eye indoor photos
Reviews.Author: carjack
Reviews.Content: I have DMC-ZS3 camera and decided to go for something more compact and DMC-ZR3 seemed like a good candidate. Unfortunately the test photos were disappointing - blurry outdoor photos in daylight (compared to the ones from ZS3) and always red-eye problem when doing indoor photos with flash. When I use ZS3 to take a photo of a person in not well lit location it will use the flash two consecutive times (with very small interval between) and the result photo almost never has red-eye problem. ZR3 doesn't seem to have this feature, even after I set the "red-eye reduction" option to "on" from the settings (appears on manual mode only, "off" be default).The movies from ZR3 are not bad (that's why I gave it 2 stars) but it has a single microphone while ZS3/ZS7 models have two - movie with stereo sound is much better then mono in almost any occasion.So I returned ZR3 and will stick to the "big-brother" models ( ZS3 and ZS7) which are a bit heavier and bigger, but have more zoom (12x vs 8x); do much clearer photos (I guess bigger lenses mean more light captured which means better photos) and are actually more comfortable to hold.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3
Reviews.Author: Yasser Khalil "Khalil23"
Reviews.Content: The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3 is an amazing camera. I love it. It is probably the best digital camera I have every used. It is very expensive so it's even better. When I tell people how much I paid they can't believe it. I would hightly recommend this camera. The picture quality is phenomenal and the battery has a long life.

Reviews.Title: Poor quality pics
Reviews.Author: Craig
Reviews.Content: The price can't be beat for all of the features packed into this camera.  Unfortunately, the features don't leave you with high quality pictures.  As others have said - great pics in high light outdoor situations, but very poor results in anything else.  I can't recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Digital Cameras for Hunting and the Outdoors
Reviews.Author: Randy Wakeman "Randy Wakeman"
Reviews.Content: from Randy Wakeman Outdoors:Digital Cameras for Hunting and the OutdoorsCameras have changed immeasurably over the years. The Eastman Kodak "Brownie" was introduced back in 1900, with millions of Brownie 127 cameras sold between 1952 and 1967. The Brownie slogan was, "You push the button, we do the rest." It was in 1948 when Edwin Land introduced the Land camera which became the Polaroid Land Camera. It was in response to daughter Jennifer's question, "Why can't I see them now?"At one time, it was all the rage, as when I was a kid film often had to mailed away for processing. Three or five weeks later, you finally knew who had their eyes closed or their tongues sticking out. My Dad still has his Polaroid Land Camera. Later, it became a niche market used by realtors and by my mentor, Ed Marlo, as you could approximate half-tones for publishing with a screened adapter."Point and Shoot" cameras have always had great appeal. The Kodak Instamatic sold some 50 million between 1963 - 1970. In 1970, the battery-powered flash bulb gave way to the self-contained pyrotechnic wonder, the "Magicube." The Kodak 110 format Pocket Instamatic came about in 1972, selling 25 million in less than three years. Times have changed, the last film camera I purchased was an Olympus 35mm Quickshooter Zoom, 35-70mm. By today's standards, it is monstrously large and heavy point and shoot, but back then it was living pretty large. We went through grocery bags of film shooting pre-illustrative photographs for several of my earlier books.Several AA-powered Canon PowerShots are still in the "collection," with the PowerShot A610 featuring a humble 4x optical zoom and 20 scene modes to go with its 5.0 megapixels. As it turns out, "megapixels" are currently the pet rock of the digital camera world. We like more "mega" everything, but image quality come from lens quality and sensor size, not just cramming more un-needed pixels onto a tiny sensor. The Mega-Pixel Myth still rages rampant, even though 5 megapixels is more than most consumers could ever want or use, even going up to 16 x 24 posters as David Pogue was able to show in the New York Times in February, 2007.Every couple of years, digital cameras get slimmer, lighter, and more feature-laden. The bulbous old Canon PowerShot A610, long ago retired from the field, looks like odd plastic rock compared to the latest digital pocket cameras, that now actually fit in pockets.The travel zoom category was more or less pioneered by Panasonic, with the 2006 model Lumix DMC-TZ1. It was the first consumer compact to offer a 10x optical zoom. For the hunter, hiker, outdoors person, it is attractive to have a unit that is handy and pocketable, yet capable of grabbing both a dazzling sunset and having enough magnification to get to whatever wildlife is encountered. In preparation for this little article from an enthusiast's point of view, I spend some quality time with a Panasonic 8x (10x intelligent) zoom DMC-ZR3 made in Japan, a Sony 10x Cyber-Shot DSC-HX7V made in China, a Nikon 18x Coolpix S9100 made in Indonesia, and a Canon 14x PowerShot SX230 HS made in Japan.One "feature," worthless as far as I'm concerned, is a GPS included with your camera so you can bore people with clumsy maps telling them the coordinates you've been to, or just leave it on and wait for your camera battery to discharge prematurely. It is hard to find products without GPS's, meaning cell phones, binoculars, and even your GPS includes a GPS. It's really dumb, but it is called "geotagging" and it is nevertheless a feature. Of the cameras mentioned, the Sony and the Canon both have it. Sony takes the trouble to tell you what direction your camera was pointed in when you took the picture, not exactly wake the President material.The consumer based digital camera, as well as higher end cell-phones, have extremely small sensors. A 1/2.5 in. sensor is actually 5.3 x 4.0mm. Most of the latest cameras (including the Nikon and Canon) have a 1/2.3 in. sensor, or 6.1 x 4.6mm. None of these camera capture in RAW, minimally processed format that more interested photo-shoppers might prefer, saving the files in JPEG compressed format. All of these cameras capture 720 HD video as well, or better. The importance of that is up to the individual.Going down the line, it is easy to eliminate cameras in my terms, although obviously different folks (including the many fine dedicated photophile sites) don't always agree. The Sony Cyber-Shot DSC-HX7V is close to a disaster, as it is turtle slow. I was able to get reasonably good output, but the camera is like a slow laptop with a lens, insisting on processing and saving at an irritatingly slow pace. It is even worse when attempting video, as it takes as much as 6 seconds before it so much as starts recording. Despite other gimmicks, like 3D shooting and a very good LCD display, this camera is just too slow to be a worthy hunting or outdoor companion.I purchased the "Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 8x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7-Inch LCD" in June of 2011 for about $167. Since then, prices have crept to about $200, although there are newer models (Panasonic DMC-FH25K 16.1MP Digital Camera with 8x Wide Angle Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7 inch LCD) that can be had for $130 or so as of this writing. Slightly smaller and lighter than the rest, it is fast and takes excellent pictures in the "dummy mode," my favorite mode. Though lacking the zoom range of the Canon and the Nikon, not having as large or as crisp of a screen, its long battery life (330 shots) and virtually fool-proof operation make it an excellent, reliable choice for the money.That leaves the two most feature-laden finalists, the Canon PowerShot SX230 HS and the Nikon Coolpix S9100. Both have upgraded, larger and crisper LCD screens. Technically, this is how they stack up, using essentially the same sensors.CANON SX230 HS 12.1 effective Megapixels (BSI-CMOS sensor)28-392mm equiv lens with optical stabilization1080p HD video and HDMI connection3.0 inch LCD with 461,000 dot resolutionISO sensitivity up to 320013 shooting modes, 11 Scene Modes, 11 Color ModesNIKON S9100 12.1 effective Megapixels (BSI-CMOS sensor)25-450mm equiv lens1080p HD video3.0 inch LCD with 921,000 dot resolution'Hybrid' VR image stabilization incorporating sensor shift and electronic stabilization (in video mode, sensor shift VR is disabled)ISO sensitivity up to 32005 shooting modes, 15 Scene Modes and 6 Effects modeThe great appeal of the Nikon is its 18x zoom compared to the 14x of the Canon. The Canon has a GPS, although a poor rendition of it. The Nikon is a bit faster, while the Canon does slightly better in high-ISO, low light applications. The Nikon shoots continuous drive at 9.5 fps compared to 3.2 fps for the Canon.Both have sharp LCD screens, the Canon a bit unusual in that it is a 16:9 aspect screen, more helpful for video than stills. Battery life is rated at 270 pictures for the Nikon vs. 210 for the Canon with the Canon's GPS turned off. Canon supplies you with a handy external charger, where the Nikon as supplied charges the battery in the camera (as did the sea-slug Sony). Extra batteries are invariably a good idea, but you'll need to buy a charger as well for the Nikon (and the Sony) if you want to continue to use your camera.For video, the Nikon shoots full-blown 1080p HD @ 30 fps, while the Canon stops at the inexplicable film frame rate of 24 fps. Both have fun and very usable slow-motion (240 fps) video modes as well, with the Canon's modes a bit easier to navigate to. Although the Nikon is better-handling in my view, it has build-quality issues. There is significant roughness, vibration, and noise when zooming, compared both to the smooth and silent Canon SX230 and the simpler Panasonic DMC-ZR3.If you are on a budget and like the idea of long battery life, the Panasonic DMC-ZR3 (or similar Lumix models) fits the bill with an easy and effective intelligent auto mode. For a true 14x optical zoom range, more manual controls, the best low-light images of the group, along with a GPS of dubious value, the Canon SX230 HS wins this match-up on the basis of both features, performance, and build quality. Its battery life is a concern, particularly when shooting video or with the GPS engaged, so for most folks a second fully-charged battery at the ready will be mandatory. The SX230 is a thoroughly satisfying hunting and outdoors companion with little question.Copyright 2012 by Randy Wakeman. All Rights Reserved.

Reviews.Title: Camera: Fragile ~ Warranty: Terrible
Reviews.Author: Dr. John
Reviews.Content: We purchased this camera to replace a Canon that had seen better days.  Overall we were very pleased with it.  Until we dropped it, in it's case, a few days ago.  We brought it to a local camera repair shop who said there was damage that could not be repaired.  The camera is just over 6 months old and we contacted Panasonic to see what our options are.  Basically, they told us to send it in and they would send us back a refurbished similar model for @ $140.00 (we paid $179.99 for it brand new!)  We were honest with the customer service rep and told her we did drop it, so I guess that goes to show you what you get for being honest!  We have friends and family who have dropped their digital cameras and they still work just fine, and others have dropped them, sent them in for repair and didn't pay a dime because they were still under Warranty.We will not purchase a Panasonic again as we feel their Warranty Policy is unfair and unethical.  We also feel that although this camera worked well, it is far too fragile and the durability is terrible.  If you have children, tend to drop things, or want to use this camera in "Real Life" and not be afraid of setting it down wrong, then this Panasonic camera is NOT for you.  If you can afford to buy a new camera twice a year and don't care if the Warranty sides with Panasonic, by all means, give them your money.We will not purchase another Panasonic product again.

Reviews.Title: Lumix ZR3
Reviews.Author: serious skills
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to use for a combination of personal/vacation and business (technical writing) documentation. So far, it has taken excellent pictures in both situations. The Intelligent Auto mode works well, and with the variety of pre-set Scene modes, there's some amount of control. Probably not enough for a photo-pro who would want to tailor every setting, but it works well for grab-and-shoot, plus some planned shots. The zoom is great, also.

Reviews.Title: Excellent bang for bucks!
Reviews.Author: Kathleen M. Delcambre
Reviews.Content: Excellent bang for your bucks! Workmanship is good; Leica lens are great. Did have to purchase a carrying case and memory card. Overall, a good product for the average consumer. Do recommend.

Reviews.Title: Impressed with photo quality, but not durability
Reviews.Author: C
Reviews.Content: Takes great photos for a point and shoot. Impressed with both outdoor and indoor photos. Red eye reduction is excellent. Camera durability is just okay. It is very lightweight, which may be a bonus to some people, but it almost seems too light/fragile. The lens cover is very delicate. I think dropping this camera once might damage or break it for good. I haven't had to worry about this as much with other cameras I've owned. This one I really need to be careful with. However, I would still recommend this camera for photo and video quality and other available features. It is very nice and I am quite happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Loved it
Reviews.Author: N. Hinson
Reviews.Content: My mom loves the red panasonic camera. It was easy for her to use and the big screen helps her see what the picture will look like.

Reviews.Title: a good camera with some issues
Reviews.Author: norm
Reviews.Content: Panasonic doesn't tell you that movies taken with the camera are not compatible with mac computers. as a result, I had to purchase a $30 program which converts the movies into a .mov format which will work on the mac and be usable with iphoto. Also, the camera does not come with a written manual and one must download it from a cd. The manual itself is less than stellar. As an example, I had to contact tech support (which is not US based creating some language issues) in order to find out how to turn the digital zoom on and off due to lack of clarity in the manual. The camera itself seems to take pictures of good quality and overall the camera is easy to use. I am left wondering whether I should have gone with the Sony or Canon instead.

Reviews.Title: Amazing pictures!
Reviews.Author: Tatiana Alfaro
Reviews.Content: OMG the pictures are amazing!  many options to use and have special and different pictures form the things you love or want to remember

Reviews.Title: Good--while it lasted.
Reviews.Author: JK
Reviews.Content: My old Exilim that I got for my 16th birthday finally broke last April, and I spent about a month researching which camera I wanted for my 21st birthday present in September.  I finally settled on the Panasonic Lumix ZR3.  In comparison to my outdated Exilim, the ZR3 was amazing.  My only complaints are that the battery life is not as good, despite having a sleep mode.  Also, the modes toggle out of position easily.And then.  It broke.  I bought a case for it right after I got it and took good care of it.But the shutter won't open all the way (so the bottom left of pictures and videos is black), and the zoom gets stuck sometimes.  I don't know much (i.e. anything) about cameras, but I gather that something is wrong with the lens.Unfortunately, a local camera store said it will cost me pretty much a new camera (200 plus 25 shipping) to send it out to get fixed.I'm sad.  Not to mention that this is EXACTLY what happened to my old Exilim... But it took my Exilim five years and seven months to malfunction in this way, and the ZR3 took seven months (isn't it just precious that they broke EXACTLY one year apart?).  With my track record, it seems that if I can keep a camera for five years (and have it last through three years of college), I probably should have been able to keep the ZR3 for a few years, too.  Now, I'm down to my 2 megapixel cell phone camera with which to document graduation.  Cool.

Reviews.Title: Everything  Great Except No Instruction Book
Reviews.Author: Alfonse
Reviews.Content: After looking for a good camera for quite some time, the reviews in this section significantly influenced my purchase of this camera.  And, so far I am not sorry I bought it.  I have one major frustration however.  The instruction book is on an enclosed CD and, if you want to have the instructions handy in the field where most pictures are taken, then you or someone you pay (like I did) must print it.  I paid a copy shop $14.00 to print and bind the 187 page booklet.  They did an amazing job.  Spiral bound, clear plastic front cover and a convenient 1/2 size (down from 81/2 X 11).  It looks and and serves its purpose just great - and, it should have been furnished by Panasonic!  I actually waited a few weeks before I used the camera so I could comply with the first line of the instructions which say "Read the instructions before using the camera".  It unfortunately took me some time to get it to the copy shop.  This comment isn't in any way intended to detract from what will probably be an excellent rating for the camera once I learn and utilize all of the functions.  But, I hope that at least one consumer product person reads this and recognizes how irritating it is not to receive FULL product instructions when we buy most consumer electronics and related items.

Reviews.Title: Really Disappointed wiht Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3
Reviews.Author: Okiri "O-Ki"
Reviews.Content: Bought the camera in July, just before our vacation abroad. Attributed lousy photos so far to getting used to the camera. But honestly, I am getting much better results with my ancient Canon than with this new one. About 80%-90% of photos are out of focus. It takes ages to photo - way too long between the time you click the shutter button and when the photo is actually taken. When taking pictures of children - or like taking pictures in a restaurant's kitchen like I did today - the mili-second is of importance. This camera isn't smart enough to adjust to different lighting conditions. To cut a long story short - hugely disappointing.I should start looking for the next one right away.By the way, I bought it because of its small size and weight and was impressed with most reviews I read and technical data. Don't be fooled: it's really small and can fit into a flexible pocket, but I am sure there are better cameras than this one.

Reviews.Title: Thoroughly disappointed
Reviews.Author: Steve G. "Steve G."
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a camera to take to DragonCon 2010 so I could post some pics and video on Facebook. There are always costumes that have to be seen to be believed. I did some research of product reviews on Amazon and CNet, and the ZR3 souned like it hit the sweet spot, especially since it allowed zooming during HD video recording. And the HD recording is indeed pretty good.The problem is, the picture quality is awful. Shots taken of the parade outside are full of glare off of buildings. I could see glass buildings doing this, but not brown marble. When I brought it inside to capture the folks posing for photo ops in their costumes, the results were pure rubbish. Grainyness is ever-present, making at least half of the pictures unpresentable. The lobby was pretty well lit, but most picture have an ugly bronzing. And if there's any source of artificial light directly in the shot, it comes out in the photo like a supernova, blotting out the object of focus. I took a picture of a Darth Maul, and what in reality was a cheap battery-lit lightsaber toy comes out in the photo glowing as brightly as in the films.I now have to spend hours cleaning these up in a photo editing program in order to achieve anything usable. Now, this is my first point-and-shoot camera, so realize I'm not disparaging it in comparison to other point-and-shoots. I'm disparaging it on simple standards of presentability.

Reviews.Title: Great gift for a new photographer!
Reviews.Author: R. Clay "Poppa Seed"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife, who has never done much photography and hasn't owned a digital camera. (Don't tell her, cause this is a Christmas present!)The camera will help her discover the joys of seeing her world; what Ansel Adams called, "the siren call of the viewfinder." Something wonderful happens when you look at a photographic image, and I can't wait for this kind of discovery to be part of her life. We travel as often as possible, and I'm eager to see how she sees the things we see when we travel -- if that makes sense.This is a great starter camera. It's not too complicated, but has the technology needed to take great photos. Using the camera will be a help to her in another way as well: she is an historical novelist, and "sees" times, places, and people who lived in other ages (Shakespeare, Monet, etc.). I believe a digital camera can help her do the research required to bring her novels to life. The images she creates will help her frame her characters and their environments, even though today's scenes are so different from the places she writes about. There is a continuum in her soul that touches past and present, and I'm eager to see what her new camera will bring to the process of writing novels.Ok, maybe this isn't strictly a review of the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3, but it is a statement of intention and hope that this gift will become a tool and a doorway for the one I love.

ProductInfo.Features:
14.1-megapixel effective recording
8X optical zoom (4X digital/32X total zoom)
2-11/16" LCD screen
Optical image stabilization
35mm equivalent focal length: 25-200mm
ProductInfo.Name: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZR3 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 8x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 2.7-Inch LCD (Silver)
